It's undeniable that the central tenets of the (US) conservatives used to be small, limited government, states rights, individual liberty, free markets, free speech, etc. With a few exceptions (such as the war on drugs and the death penalty), conservatives were basically a more moderate version of libertarian, and there was a lot of spillover from one to the other.

However in the past few years that has definitely changed. I haven't seen it in its purest form since about a decade ago or maybe even before that, but it's really picked up in the past 1-2 years. Conservatives are now suddenly demanding a strong state, control of the people, censorship, tough laws banning things they determined have a negative impact on society, more restricted individual rights, etc. They've basically become the left with a right-wing agenda. This was a really fast change and it's been shocking to me; I still have trouble believing it. What's the hardest is seeing all my conservative friends changing at once and suddenly going from mostly believers in freedom to solid authoritarians in a really short time. Their fundamental philosophy is such the opposite of what it was, and to me this major shift in thinking is a complete mystery. Ironically, they now closely resemble Joe Biden in his younger days of politics. Of course I still know of many people who believe in the old philosophy, but the majority of their former allies no longer do and now regard them as traitors. Knowing your enemy is necessary to fight them effectively.

About ten years ago on reddit a subreddit called ShitRedditSays was created by SomethingAweful users. Its stated goal was to stomp out misogyny and other badthink on reddit. 

Back then reddit was a pretty nice place. Those were the days of Ron Paul and the place was full of techies and libertarians. You could speak your mind in larger subreddits without being instantly banned. Free speech was still something that was universally valued.

The actual goals of SRS were entirely different. Let's say you and a small group of your friends wanted to take down reddit. How would you go about it? A direct attack would surely fail. But there are tactics that work against larger institutions, and that is using the weaknesses of that institution to make it attack itself from within. 

Their tactics included:

 - Coordination outside of reddit
 - Mass reporting of posts and subreddits
 - Coordinating with the media to publish hit pieces
 - Attacking fringe communities
 - False flag attacks: posting content that was illegal or against reddit rules to get subreddits banned
 - Kept lists of users and subreddits to target
 - Worked with reddit admins or had admin sympathizers

I'm sure there were other, more nefarious tactics used, but I haven't witnessed them personally.

They seem to derive pleasure from exercising their power and destroying what others have built. They are the kind of people who find pleasure in destroying another kid's sandcastle rather than building their own.

Other subreddits were created later, like AgainstHateSubreddits, which used similar tactics. 

Partly through their efforts reddit is what it is today.

That brings us to the cabal that has infested ruqqus. It's obvious they are they same people, if not physically, then in spirit. Their stated goal is ridding ruqqus of nazis and other wrongthink (Ruqqus Correction Project). Knowing your enemy is necessary to fight them effectively.

About ten years ago on reddit a subreddit called ShitRedditSays was created by SomethingAweful users. Its stated goal was to stomp out misogyny and other badthink on reddit. 

Back then reddit was a pretty nice place. Those were the days of Ron Paul and the place was full of techies and libertarians. You could speak your mind in larger subreddits without being instantly banned. Free speech was still something that was universally valued.

The actual goals of SRS were entirely different. Let's say you and a small group of your friends wanted to take down reddit. How would you go about it? A direct attack would surely fail. But there are tactics that work against larger institutions, and that is using the weaknesses of that institution to make it attack itself from within. 

Their tactics included:

 - Coordination outside of reddit
 - Mass reporting of posts and subreddits
 - Coordinating with the media to publish hit pieces
 - Attacking fringe communities
 - False flag attacks: posting content that was illegal or against reddit rules to get subreddits banned
 - Kept lists of users and subreddits to target
 - Worked with reddit admins or had admin sympathizers

I'm sure there were other, more nefarious tactics used, but I haven't witnessed them personally.

They seem to derive pleasure from exercising their power and destroying what others have built. They are the kind of people who find pleasure in destroying another kid's sandcastle rather than building their own.

Other subreddits were created later, like AgainstHateSubreddits, which used similar tactics. 

Partly through their efforts reddit is what it is today.

That brings us to the cabal that has infested ruqqus. It's obvious they are they same people, if not physically, then in spirit. Their stated goal is ridding ruqqus of nazis and other wrongthink (Ruqqus Correction Project). They keep a [list of badthink guilds](https://ruqqus.com/+AgainstChudGuilds/post/372n/how-to-detox-your-feed-a). They seize guilds with the sole purpose of destroying them, as we've seen recently with +HitlerWasRight and others. They coordinate offsite on discord. 

Behind their outwardly "noble" goals of ridding ruqqus of "nazis" is the same desire to destroy. If they are ever successful at getting rid of "nazis" they will just find some other fringe group to attack. They will not stop until ruqqus is dead.
